--- title: "Reticulate" author: "Nina Norgren" image: "assets/featured.jpg" format: revealjs --- ## Packages {visibility="hidden"} ::: {.cell} ::: ## Learning outcomes
In this session we will learn to: - Understand the concepts needed for running Python in R - Understand the different object classes in Python and their equivalent in R - Apply our knowledge to: - Import Python functions into R - Use R objects as input to Python functions - Translate between Python and R objects ## Introduction

[**R versus Python**]{.center .larger} [The ultimate fight!]{.center .largest} . . .


[Not anymore!]{.center .largest} ## Introducing reticulate - Combine Python and R code - Use R classes in Python functions and vice versa - Import Python functions into R code and run from R - Add Python code chunks to markdown documents ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(reticulate) ``` ::: ## Importing Python modules ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} datetime <- import("datetime") todays_r_date <- datetime$datetime$now() ``` ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} todays_r_date class(todays_r_date) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "2023-06-08 10:20:12 CEST" [1] "POSIXct" "POSIXt" ``` ::: ::: . . . Objects are automatically converted to R types, unless otherwise specified . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} datetime <- import("datetime", convert = FALSE) todays_py_date <- datetime$datetime$now() ``` ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} todays_py_date class(todays_py_date) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` datetime.datetime(2023, 6, 8, 10, 20, 12, 742662) [1] "datetime.datetime" "datetime.date" "python.builtin.object" ``` ::: ::: ## Importing built-in Python functions Access Python's built-in functions directly in R ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} builtins <- import_builtins() r_vec <- c(1, 5, 3, 4, 2, 2, 3, 2) str(r_vec) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` num [1:8] 1 5 3 4 2 2 3 2 ``` ::: ::: `r_vec` is an R object. . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} builtins$len(r_vec); builtins$max(r_vec) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 8 [1] 5 ``` ::: ::: Python built-in functions still working on R objects . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} max(r_vec) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 5 ``` ::: ::: Normal R way ## Sourcing scripts Import your own python functions for use in R. File `python_functions.py`: ::: {.cell} ```{.python .cell-code} def add(x, y): return x + y ``` ::: . . . R code: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} source_python("python_functions.py") class(4) res <- add(4,5) res class(res) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "numeric" [1] 9 [1] "numeric" ``` ::: ::: . . . Type `numeric` in and type `numeric` out. But what happens in between? ## Sourcing scripts But what happens in between? File `python_functions.py`: ::: {.cell} ```{.python .cell-code} def add_with_print(x, y): print(x, 'is of the python type ', type(x)) return x + y ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} res2 <- add_with_print(4,5) py_capture_output(add_with_print(4,5)) str(res2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "4.0 is of the python type \n\n" num 9 ``` ::: ::: ## Execute Python code Run python string: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} py_run_string("result = [1,2,3]*2") py$result ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 2 3 1 2 3 ``` ::: ::: All objects created by python are accessible using the `py` object exported by **reticulate** ## Execute Python code Run python script `my_python_script.py`: ::: {.cell} ```{.python .cell-code} def add(x, y): return x + y def multiply_by_3(x): return x*3 def run_all(): x = 5 y = 8 added = add(x, y) final = multiply_by_3(added) return final final = run_all() ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} py_run_file("my_python_script.py") py$final ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 39 ``` ::: ::: ## Python in R Markdown In R Markdown, it is possible to mix in Python chunks: ```` ```{{python}} import pandas as pd movies = get_all_movies() print(type(movies)) ``` ```` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` ``` ::: ::: ## Python in R Markdown Access the movie object using the `py` object, which will convert movies to an R object: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} movies_r <- py$movies movies_r <- as_tibble(movies_r) subset <- movies_r %>% select(5:6, 8:10) ``` ::: ## Python in R Markdown Access the movie object using the `py` object, which will convert movies to an R object: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} movies_r <- py$movies movies_r <- as_tibble(movies_r) subset <- movies_r %>% select(5:6, 8:10) knitr::kable(subset[1:7,],'html') ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
originalTitle startYear runtimeMinutes genres averageRating
Kate & Leopold 2001 118 Comedy,Fantasy,Romance 6.4
The Brain That Wouldn't Die 1962 82 Horror,Sci-Fi 4.4
The Fugitive Kind 1960 119 Drama,Romance 7.1
Les yeux sans visage 1960 90 Drama,Horror 7.7

The Alamo 1960 162 Adventure,Drama,History 6.8
````` ::: ::: ## Python in R Markdown Continue working with the now converted R object in R ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(movies_r, aes(x=startYear)) + geom_bar() + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90)) + ggtitle('Number of movies per year') ``` ::: ## Python in R Markdown Continue working with the now converted R object in R ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(movies_r, aes(x=startYear)) + geom_bar() + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90)) + ggtitle('Number of movies per year') ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-21-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Type conversions When calling python code from R, R data types are converted to Python types, and vice versa, when values are returned from Python to R they are converted back to R types. [**Conversion table**]{.large} ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
R Python Examples
Single-element vector Scalar 1 , 1L , TRUE, foo
Multi-element vector List c(1.0, 2.0, 3.0), c(1L, 2L, 3L)
List of multiple types Tuple list(1L, TRUE, "foo")
Named list Dict list(a = 1L, b = 2.0), dict(x = x_data)
Matrix/Array NumPy ndarray matrix(c(1,2,3,4), nrow=2, ncol=2)
Data Frame Pandas DataFrame data.frame(x = c(1,2,3), y = c("a","b","c"))
Function Python function function(x) x +1
Raw Python bytearray as.raw(c(1:10))
NULL, TRUE, FALSE None, True, False NULL, TRUE, FALSE
````` ::: ::: ## Type conversions `python_functions.py`: ::: {.cell} ```{.python .cell-code} def check_python_type(x): print(type(x)) return x ``` ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} source_python("python_functions.py") r_var <- matrix(c(1,2,3,4),nrow=2, ncol=2) class(r_var) py_capture_output(check_python_type(r_var)) r_var2 <- check_python_type(r_var) class(r_var2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "matrix" "array" [1] "\n\n" [1] "matrix" "array" ``` ::: ::: ## Type conversions ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} source_python("python_functions.py", convert=FALSE) r_var <- matrix(c(1,2,3,4),nrow=2, ncol=2) class(r_var) py_capture_output(check_python_type(r_var)) r_var2 <- check_python_type(r_var) class(r_var2) r_var3 <- py_to_r(r_var2) class(r_var3) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "matrix" "array" [1] "\n\n" [1] "numpy.ndarray" "python.builtin.object" [1] "matrix" "array" ``` ::: ::: ## Type conversions - `42` in R is a floating point number. In Python it is an integer ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} str(42) check_python_type(42) py_capture_output(check_python_type(42)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` num 42 42.0 [1] "\n\n" ``` ::: ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} str(42L) check_python_type(42L) py_capture_output(check_python_type(42L)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` int 42 42 [1] "\n\n" ``` ::: ::: ## Type conversions - List conversions of single element vectors, automatically translated to Python scalar ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} str(c(24)) check_python_type(c(24)) py_capture_output(check_python_type(c(24))) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` num 24 24.0 [1] "\n\n" ``` ::: ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} str(list(24)) check_python_type(list(24)) py_capture_output(check_python_type(list(24))) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` List of 1 $ : num 24 [24.0] [1] "\n\n" ``` ::: ::: ## {background-image="../../assets/images/cover.jpg"} ### Thank you! <script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
